responses.text: Agile is a way of developing software that prioritizes flexibility, teamwork, and customer satisfaction. Instead of having a strict plan from the start and following it, the Agile approach involves regularly checking in and making changes along the way based on what is learned and what the customer wants. The goal is to deliver a useful product as quickly as possible and to be able to respond to changes along the way ÔëâClick here for more Info.

patterns: tell me about History of Agile

why is agile need to known

responses.text: The Agile methodology originated in the software development industry as a new way to manage software development. Many software development projects were failing or taking much too long to complete, and industry leaders realized they needed to find a new, innovative approach. In 2001, the Manifesto for Agile Software Development was created.

patterns: can you tell what is Agile Manifesto?
i need to find what is Agile Manifesto
can you find me what is Agile Manifesto

responses.text: The Agile Manifesto is a document that identifies four key values and 12 principles that guide software development. The Manifesto for Agile Software Development, it was produced by 17 developers during an outing on Feb. 11-13, 2001, at The Lodge at Snowbird ski resort in Utah.

patterns: can you tell what is Agile Values?
i need to find what is Agile Values
can you find me what is Agile Values
how would agile values would help ?

responses.text: Agile Values refers to the set of 4 values outlined by the Agile Alliance in The Agile Manifesto. This set of values encourages putting people before processes, getting software out the door fast, collaborating with customers, and adjusting plans as needed.

patterns: can you tell what is Agile Principles?
i need to find what is Agile Principles
can you find me what is Agile Principles

responses.text: There are 12 Agile Principles outlined in The Agile Manifesto in addition to the 4 agile values. These 12 principles for agile software development help establish the tenets of the agile mindset. Agile principles support observing changing markets, customer needs, and competitive threats and changing course when necessary.

patterns: can you tell what is SCRUM?
i need to find what is SCRUM
can you find me what is SCRUM

responses.text: Scrum is an agile project management framework that helps team structure and manage their work through a set of values, principles, and practices. It is an iterative approach, consisting of sprints that typically only last one to four weeks. This approach ensures that the teams deliver value incrementally in a collaborative way.

patterns: tell me about Three Pillars of Scrum
can you tell what is Three Pillars of Scrum?
do you know Three Pillars of Scrum?

what is Three Pillars of Scrum?

responses.text: Scrum is based on the theory of empirical process control, which relies on Transparency, Inspection, & Adaptation.

patterns: can you tell what is Scrum Values?
i need to find what is Scrum Values
can you find me what is Scrum Values

responses.text: The Scrum Values of Courage, Focus, Commitment, Respect, and Openness, are all important elements that Scrum Team members must consider when working together. The Scrum Values are particularly important in environments where experimentation is core to making progress.

responses.text: The people on the Scrum Team

data.title: Scrum Master üéì
data.description: The person on the Scrum Team who uses their knowledge of Scrum to help the team and organization to be as effective as they can be; they do so by taking approaches like coaching, teaching, facilitating and mentoring.

data.title: Product Owner üë®‚Äçüíº
data.description: The person on the Scrum Team who makes sure that the team is creating the most valuable product they can create.

data.title: Developers üë®‚Äçüë¶‚Äçüë¶
data.description: The people on the Scrum Team who work together to create the product.

patterns: can you tell what is Scrum Events?
i need to find what is Scrum Events
can you find me what is Scrum Events

responses.text: Events that create regularity and minimize other meetings

data.title: Sprint
data.description: Short cycles of one month or less, during which the work is done; the Sprint contains all of the other Scrum events; a new Sprint starts immediately after the conclusion of the previous Sprint.

data.title: Sprint Planning
data.description: Event dedicated to planning out the work that will take place during the Sprint.

data.title: Daily Scrum
data.description: Event held every day where the Developers inspect the progress toward the Sprint Goal, uncover anything that may be getting in their way and adapt accordingly.

data.title: Sprint Review
data.description: Event held at the end of the Sprint where the Scrum Team and key stakeholders review what was accomplished in the Sprint and what has changed in their environment; next, attendees collaborate on what to do next.

data.title: Sprint Retrospective
data.description: The Scrum Team gets together during this event to talk about how the last Sprint went and identify the most helpful changes to improve their effectiveness.

patterns: can you tell what is Scrum Artifacts?
i need to find what is Scrum Artifacts
can you find me what is Scrum Artifacts

responses.text: The plans and work which are transparent and can be inspected allowing for future adaptation; Each artifact has its own Commitment which helps the team understand if they are making progress

data.title: Product Backlog
data.description: An evolving, ordered list of what is needed to improve the product; it is the single source of work undertaken by the Scrum Team.

data.title: Commitment
data.description: Product Goal-the target the team plans against.

data.title: Sprint Backlog
data.description: A highly visible list of work that is the Developer‚Äôs plan for the Sprint, which may evolve as they learn.

data.title: Commitment
data.description: Sprint Goal- the single objective of the Sprint.

data.title: Increments
data.description: Small pieces of work that serve as concrete stepping stones toward the Product Goal. You can deliver as often as needed during the Sprint and are not limited to only one release per Sprint.

data.title: Commitment
data.description: Definition of Done- the description of what it takes for an Increment to be considered complete.

data.title: Burndown Charts
data.description: A sprint burndown (or burnup) chart is not an official scrum artifact, but many teams use it to communicate and track progress toward the sprint goal during the sprint.

patterns: can you tell what is Kanban?
i need to find what is Kanban
can you find me what is Kanban

responses.text: Kanban is a popular Lean workflow management method for defining, managing, and improving services that deliver knowledge work. It helps you visualize work, maximize efficiency, and improve continuously. Work is represented on Kanban boards, allowing you to optimize work delivery across multiple teams and handle even the most complex projects in a single environment.

patterns: can you tell what is History?
i need to find what is History
can you find me what is History

responses.text: Taiichi Ohno introduced kanban at Toyota in the late 1940s. He was an industrial engineer and eventual executive at the company. Today he is considered the 'father' of the Toyota Production System, which inspired lean manufacturing in the United States. At the time, Toyota was struggling to compete with the American car market. So, Toyota looked at how other supply chains handled fulfillment by matching inventory levels with consumption patterns. This research led Toyota to see consumer demand as part of the manufacturing process ‚Äî a required input precedent to production. Ohno aimed to eliminate overproduction by introducing new inventory only when absolutely necessary. Factories were reorganized so that parts production and assembly happened at the same rate, with assembly workers taking parts only as needed. They called it the 'just in time' (JiT) method ‚Äî but more on that later.

patterns: can you tell what is Definition?
i need to find what is Definition
can you find me what is Definition

responses.text: The Kanban Method is a means to design, manage, and improve flow systems for knowledge work. The method also allows organizations to start with their existing workflow and drive evolutionary change. They can do this by visualizing their flow of work, limit work in progress (WIP) and stop starting and start finishing. The Kanban Method gets its name from the use of kanban - visual signaling mechanisms to control work in progress for intangible work products.

patterns: can you tell what is Principles?
i need to find what is Principles
can you find me what is Principles

responses.text: David J. Anderson (a pioneer in the field of Lean/ Kanban for knowledge work and one of the founding fathers of the method) has formulated the Kanban method as an approach to incremental, evolutionary process and systems change for knowledge work organizations. It is focused on getting things done, and its fundamentals can be broken down into two types of principles and six practices.

patterns: i need to find what is Core Practices
can you find me what is Core Practices

responses.text: While there are some overlaps with other Agile frameworks, Kanban is based on pull systems which allow you to start work where there is demand for a deliverable. As opposed to a time-based approach like Scrum, where sprints and events follow strict schedules. There are 6 Core Kanban Practices Ôëá

responses.text: According to the 1st State of Kanban report, the leading reasons for adopting the Kanban method are the need for enhanced visibility of work and continuous improvement.

patterns: tell me about Agile Project Management
can you tell Agile Project Management
i need to find what is Agile Project Management
can you find me what is Agile Project Management
how do we manage with agile

responses.text: Agile project management is an iterative approach to managing software development projects that focuses on continuous releases and incorporating customer feedback with every iteration. The ability to adjust during each iteration promotes velocity and adaptability. This approach is different from a linear, waterfall project management approach, which follows a set path with limited deviation.

patterns: tell me about Benefits of Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)
can you tell Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)
i need to find what is Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)
can you find me what is Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)

responses.text: The scaled agile framework (SAFe) is a set of organization and workflow patterns intended to guide enterprises in scaling lean and agile practices. The framework is a body of knowledge that includes structured guidance on roles and responsibilities, how to plan and manage the work, and values to uphold. SAFe promotes alignment, collaboration, and delivery across large numbers of agile teams. It was formed around three primary bodies of knowledge: agile software development, lean product development, and systems thinking.

patterns: tell me about History of SAFe
can you tell History of SAFe
i need to find what is History of SAFe
can you find me what is History of SAFe

responses.text: In 2011, the SAFe framework gained recognition in the product world. Software-Industry veteran Dean Leffingwell, the author of Agile Software Requirements, originally called the SAFe framework the 'Agile Enterprise Big Picture.' The 'Big Picture' described how to leverage existing agile frameworks such as Lean, Kanban, Scrum, and XP and apply them at the Team, Program, and Portfolio. SAFe remains one of the most popular agile frameworks. Below is a quick view of the Framework‚Äôs history.

patterns: tell me about SAFe Core Values
can you tell SAFe Core Values
i need to find what is SAFe Core Values
can you find me what is SAFe Core Values

responses.text: The four core values of SAFe are alignment, built-in quality, transparency, and program execution. They all work together to align organizations so that they meet their desired goals. SAFe is very instrumental in large teams and focuses both on business systems and outcomes.

patterns: i need to find what is SAFe Principles
can you find me what is SAFe Principles
what are the principles of SAFe?

responses.text: SAFe is based on ten immutable, underlying Lean-Agile principles. These tenets and economic concepts inspire and inform the roles and practices of SAFe.

patterns: i need to find what is SAFe Configurations
can you find me what is SAFe Configurations
responses:
SAFe supports the full range of development environments with four out-of-the-box configurations. The configurations are described as below
Essential SAFe - is the most basic configuration. It describes the most critical elements needed and is intended to provide the majority of the framework's benefits. It includes the team and program level.Essential SAFe Link Ôîó
Large Solution SAFe ‚Äì allows for coordination and synchronization across multiple programs, but without the portfolio considerations. In earlier versions of SAFe, this level was referred to as¬†value stream.Large Solution SAFe Link Ôîó
Portfolio SAFe - includes concerns for strategic direction, investment funding, and lean governance.Portfolio SAFe Link Ôîó
Full SAFe - combines the other three levels. Full SAFe is the most comprehensive configuration, including all seven core competencies needed for business agility.Full SAFe Link Ôîó

patterns: tell me about 7 core competencies of SAFe?
can you tell 7 core competencies of SAFe
do you 7 core competencies of SAFe
i need to find what is 7 core competencies of SAFe
can you find me what is 7 core competencies of SAFe
what is 7 core competencies of SAFe?
responses:
SAFe constantly adapts to the current situation of the market and continuously provides updates of the framework to its users. The current edition, SAFe 5, is built around seven core competencies (with additional core competencies in comparison to older versions). Each of the seven core competencies are essential to achieve Business Agility. Each of the competencies is supported by an assessment specific to the competency. These assessments enable the organization to assess their proficiency. The seven core competencies are
1. Lean-Agile Leadership(LINK Ôîó)
2. Team and Technical Agility(LINK Ôîó)
3. Agile Product Delivery(LINK Ôîó)
4. Enterprise Solution Delivery(LINK Ôîó)
5. Lean Portfolio Management(LINK Ôîó)
6. Organizational Agility(LINK Ôîó)
7. Continuous Learning Culture(LINK Ôîó)
